pending_diagnosis: DIAGNOSIS: The patient suffered a late-onset presentation of Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) Deficiency, the most common inherited disorder of the urea cycle. THE SMOKING GUN: The constellation of extreme, acute hyperammonemia (>400 umol/L) combined with a presentation following a period of profound high-protein load and significant catabolic stress (intense training), and the absence of both severe ketoacidosis and hypoglycemia, pointed definitively toward a Urea Cycle Disorder (UCD). Subsequent plasma amino acid chromatography showed profoundly low citrulline and arginine, and urine organic acid analysis revealed high orotic acid—the specific biochemical signature of OTC deficiency. PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: OTC is an essential enzyme in the mitochondria responsible for converting carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine into citrulline. OTC deficiency is X-linked. While severe forms present in neonates, attenuated mutations (late-onset) can remain asymptomatic until triggered by significant metabolic stress (infection, fever, starvation, or, as in this case, a high-protein anabolic load). Failure of the urea cycle leads to the rapid, toxic accumulation of ammonia (NH3) in the bloodstream. Ammonia crosses the blood-brain barrier, converting astrocytes into Alzheimer Type II cells, leading to cerebral swelling, intracranial hypertension, and irreversible neurological damage (encephalopathy). Immediate treatment requires protein restriction, ammonia scavengers (sodium phenylacetate/benzoate), and often emergent hemodialysis or continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) to rapidly clear the ammonia.
